title: How to break out of autopilot and create the life you want | Graham Weaver (Stanford GSB professor)
themes: The psychology of success and fulfillment
key_insights: Ask yourself 'What would you do if you knew you wouldn't fail?' to discover your true career passion
Everything you want is on the other side of 'worse first' - initial steps toward meaningful change are always difficult
Write down limiting beliefs to strip them of power and turn them into actionable to-do items
Most people operate 95-98% from their subconscious mind, making intentional decision-making crucial
Create accountability through executive coaching or structured goal-setting with peers
Success often takes 10-20 years longer than expected - persistence is the key differentiator
Financial success alone doesn't create fulfillment - internal work is essential for happiness
The phrase 'not now' often becomes 'not ever' - there's never a perfect time to pursue your dreams

guest_background.current_role: Founder and CEO of Alpine Investors (private equity) and Professor at Stanford Graduate School of Business

topics_discussed: The genie framework for discovering career passion
Nine lives exercise for exploring different life paths
The internal vs external game of life
When to quit vs when to persist
The role of suffering in meaningful pursuits
Financial success and its psychological impact
Failure stories and learning from setbacks
memorable_quotes: Life is suffering, so choose something worth suffering for
Everything you want is on the other side of worse first
Don't ask what the world needs. Ask instead what makes you come alive, because what the world needs most is for you to come alive
frameworks_mentioned: Daily Goal Setting with Three Actions
summary: Stanford professor and successful private equity founder Graham Weaver shares practical frameworks for discovering your life purpose and breaking out of autopilot mode. The episode provides actionable exercises like the 'genie framework' and addresses the psychology of meaningful career transitions, emphasizing that fulfillment comes from following your internal scorecard rather than external expectations.
